comment_text.mn83:1.1: Versions of this story are told in the Maghadeva Jātaka (Ja 9) and Nimi Jātaka (Ja 541).
comment_text.mn83:1.2: Mithilā was the capital of Videha, to the north east of the Vajjian federation, nestled against the Himalayas. Mithilā was a dominant kingdom before the Buddha, its king Janaka featuring prominently in early Upaniṣads. It features rarely in the suttas (MN 91, Thig 6.2, Thig 13.4) and had apparently declined in importance. It is unclear whether Mithilā had been subsumed into the Vajjian federation or remained as a minor independent kingdom until conquered by Magadha some years later. DN 19:36.7 establishes the mythic origins of the land from a Buddhist perspective, whereas Śatapatha Brāhmaṇa 1.4.1.10–19 depicts its origins in terms of the spread of fire-worship from the west by the founding king Māthava Videgha with his priest Gotama Rāhūgaṇa.
comment_text.mn83:3.1: Maghadeva (“bounteous god”) is from the Vedic magha (“bounty”; see SN 11.12:1.3). Pali variants are makhādeva and māghadeva, while Sanskrit sources usually have mahādeva; a Bharhut stūpa inscription has maghādeva. | For “stood by his duty” (dhamme ṭhito) compare “standing by the tree’s duty” (rukkhadhamme ṭhito) at AN 6.54:12.4. In such instances, dhamma anticipates the later Hindu notion of svadharma, i.e. the duty appropriate for ones’ station.
comment_text.mn83:4.1: Maghadeva’s story of renunciation shares much in common with that of Daḷhanemi (DN 26:2.1).
comment_text.mn83:4.6: Such “messengers of the gods” appear as reminders for the dangers of mortality in MN 130 and AN 3.36.
comment_text.mn83:4.8: This event is depicted in a Barhut relief.
comment_text.mn83:4.13: It is an expected virtue of a good ruler to retire when signs of aging appear. | The notion that spiritual practice is for the elderly is expressed at Bi Pc 21:1.4, where sex workers teased nuns, suggesting they enjoy themselves while young and ordain when old. The Buddhist position is that Dhamma can be practiced at any age.
comment_text.mn83:4.15: The signs of the renunciate predate Buddhism.
comment_text.mn83:6.1: 84,000 is 12 times 7 times 1000, where 12 is the months of the year (a full cycle) and in addition, a multiple of 4, the number of fullness and balance. 7 signifies the entire cycle of birth and death, being the days of the week and the visible “planets” (Sun, Moon, Mercury, Venus, Mars, Jupiter, and Saturn). 1000 is a major multiplier. Thus the overall sense of 84,000 is an abundant fullness (especially of time), in which sense it became a popular mystic number in Buddhism.
comment_text.mn83:6.2: Living the “spiritual (divine) life” (brahmacariya), he practiced the “divine meditations” (brahmavihāra) and was reborn in the “divine realm of Brahmā” (brahmaloka). The Buddha is presenting an idealized vision of the ancient Brahmanical path as a coherent spiritual practice guided by the notion of brahma as spiritual or divine excellence (see too MN 99:22.14, DN 13:38.2). | As the exemplar of an ideal Brahmanized king, Maghadeva is perhaps to be identified with Māthava Videgha, the founder and Brahmanizer of Mithilā. His name ought probably be read mādhava (“possessor of madhu”) where madhu (“honey”) is a common term for Soma. Māthava Videgha was the first king who carried out the Soma rites in the region, bringing Agni to “burn over” (civilize) the newly-brahmanized land.
comment_text.mn83:11.4: This totals 28.224 billion years, while the current estimate of the age of the Universe is half that at about 13.8 billion years; we are estimated to be less than half way through the current Universe. Thus the Buddhist scope of time falls within the same order of magnitude as modern cosmology. Similar durations emerge from different contexts in the suttas. The lifespan of the lowest Brahma realm is implied to be 37 billion years (AN 3.70:34.4), while the duration in hell is about 25 billion (AN 10.89:15.3 = Snp 3.10:8.1).
comment_text.mn83:12.1: Nimi is widely known in Sanskrit literature as one of the three main sons of Ikṣvāku (Okkāka), the legendary ancestor of the solar dynasty and the source of the Sakyan royal lineage (Bhāgavata Purāṇa 9.6.4). As the king of Videha, Nimi was the direct ancestor of Mahājanaka (Rāmāyaṇa 1.71.3). While his legends underwent proliferation, it seems the kernel of the story is common, as Mahābhārata says that “Nimi, the ruler of the Videhas, gave away his kingdom” (14.234 of Kisari Mohan Ganguli’s translation).
comment_text.mn83:13.13: For “sing his praises” (kittayamānarūpā) see DN 18:4.8.
comment_text.mn83:14.9: Despite this, no journey to the lower realms is mentioned here, which perhaps indicates textual loss. It is, however, told in detail in Ja 541.
comment_text.mn83:15.15: PTS and BJT editions have the expected upavasissāmi (“I shall observe”) for Mahāsaṅgīti’s upavasāmi (“I observe”).
comment_text.mn83:20.1: The Janakas were the famed kingly house of Videha, here framed as the source of the kingdom’s decline. A King Janaka was Sītā’s father in the Rāmāyaṇa, and one discussed philosophy with Yājñavalkya in the Bṛhadāraṇyaka Upaniṣad. A Janaka is also featured in the Jātakas (Ja 539). It seems impossible to determine which, if any, are the same person.
comment_text.mn83:21.7: According to the doctrine of the “perfections” (pāramī), which emerged around two to four centuries after the Buddha’s passing, the practices he undertook in past lives laid the foundation for awakening in this life. Here, however, the Buddha states that his former practices did not lead to awakening. Rather, since they were based on the wrong view of eternal bliss in the Brahmā realm, they only led to a good rebirth so long as that kamma lasted. It is the eightfold path, which the Buddha discovered in his final life, which leads to awakening. The same saying in a similar context is found at DN 19:61.4.
comment_text.mn83:21.14: The Buddha changes to the plural so as to include the whole Saṅgha.

root_text.mn83:15.7: “lābhā vata, bho, videhānaṁ, suladdhaṁ vata, bho, videhānaṁ,
root_text.mn83:15.8: yesaṁ nimi rājā dhammiko dhammarājā dhamme ṭhito mahārājā;
root_text.mn83:15.9: dhammaṁ carati brāhmaṇagahapatikesu negamesu ceva jānapadesu ca;
root_text.mn83:15.10: uposathañca upavasati cātuddasiṁ pañcadasiṁ aṭṭhamiñca pakkhassā”ti.
root_text.mn83:15.14: Tathāhaṁ dhammaṁ carissāmi brāhmaṇagahapatikesu negamesu ceva jānapadesu ca;
root_text.mn83:15.15: uposathañca upavasāmi cātuddasiṁ pañcadasiṁ aṭṭhamiñca pakkhassā’ti.
root_text.mn83:16.1: Atha kho, ānanda, sakko devānamindo mātaliṁ saṅgāhakaṁ āmantesi:
root_text.mn83:16.2: ‘ehi tvaṁ, samma mātali, sahassayuttaṁ ājaññarathaṁ yojetvā nimiṁ rājānaṁ tattheva mithilaṁ paṭinehī’ti.
root_text.mn83:16.3: ‘Evaṁ, bhaddantavā’ti kho, ānanda, mātali saṅgāhako sakkassa devānamindassa paṭissutvā sahassayuttaṁ ājaññarathaṁ yojetvā nimiṁ rājānaṁ tattheva mithilaṁ paṭinesi.
root_text.mn83:16.4: Tatra sudaṁ, ānanda, nimi rājā dhammaṁ carati brāhmaṇagahapatikesu negamesu ceva jānapadesu ca, uposathañca upavasati cātuddasiṁ pañcadasiṁ aṭṭhamiñca pakkhassāti.
root_text.mn83:16.5: Atha kho, ānanda, nimi rājā bahūnaṁ vassānaṁ bahūnaṁ vassasatānaṁ bahūnaṁ vassasahassānaṁ accayena kappakaṁ āmantesi:
root_text.mn83:16.6: ‘yadā me, samma kappaka, passeyyāsi sirasmiṁ palitāni jātāni, atha me āroceyyāsī’ti.
root_text.mn83:16.7: ‘Evaṁ, devā’ti kho, ānanda, kappako nimissa rañño paccassosi.
root_text.mn83:16.8: Addasā kho, ānanda, kappako bahūnaṁ vassānaṁ bahūnaṁ vassasatānaṁ bahūnaṁ vassasahassānaṁ accayena nimissa rañño sirasmiṁ palitāni jātāni.
root_text.mn83:16.12: ‘Tena hi, samma kappaka, tāni palitāni sādhukaṁ saṇḍāsena uddharitvā mama añjalismiṁ patiṭṭhāpehī’ti.
root_text.mn83:16.13: ‘Evaṁ, devā’ti kho, ānanda, kappako nimissa rañño paṭissutvā tāni palitāni sādhukaṁ saṇḍāsena uddharitvā nimissa rañño añjalismiṁ patiṭṭhāpesi.
root_text.mn83:16.14: Atha kho, ānanda, nimi rājā kappakassa gāmavaraṁ datvā jeṭṭhaputtaṁ kumāraṁ āmantāpetvā etadavoca:
root_text.mn83:16.17: bhuttā kho pana me mānusakā kāmā;
root_text.mn83:16.19: Ehi tvaṁ, tāta kumāra, imaṁ rajjaṁ paṭipajja.
root_text.mn83:16.20: Ahaṁ pana kesamassuṁ ohāretvā kāsāyāni vatthāni acchādetvā agārasmā anagāriyaṁ pabbajissāmi.
root_text.mn83:16.21: Tena hi, tāta kumāra, yadā tvampi passeyyāsi sirasmiṁ palitāni jātāni, atha kappakassa gāmavaraṁ datvā jeṭṭhaputtaṁ kumāraṁ sādhukaṁ rajje samanusāsitvā kesamassuṁ ohāretvā kāsāyāni vatthāni acchādetvā agārasmā anagāriyaṁ pabbajeyyāsi.
root_text.mn83:16.22: Yena me idaṁ kalyāṇaṁ vattaṁ nihitaṁ anuppavatteyyāsi, mā kho me tvaṁ antimapuriso ahosi.
root_text.mn83:16.23: Yasmiṁ kho, tāta kumāra, purisayuge vattamāne evarūpassa kalyāṇassa vattassa samucchedo hoti so tesaṁ antimapuriso hoti.
root_text.mn83:16.24: Taṁ tāhaṁ, tāta kumāra, evaṁ vadāmi:
root_text.mn83:16.25: “yena me idaṁ kalyāṇaṁ vattaṁ nihitaṁ anuppavatteyyāsi, mā kho me tvaṁ antimapuriso ahosī”’ti.
root_text.mn83:17-19.1: Atha kho, ānanda, nimi rājā kappakassa gāmavaraṁ datvā jeṭṭhaputtaṁ kumāraṁ sādhukaṁ rajje samanusāsitvā imasmiṁyeva maghadevaambavane kesamassuṁ ohāretvā kāsāyāni vatthāni acchādetvā agārasmā anagāriyaṁ pabbaji.
root_text.mn83:17-19.2: So mettāsahagatena cetasā ekaṁ disaṁ pharitvā vihāsi, tathā dutiyaṁ, tathā tatiyaṁ, tathā catutthaṁ; iti uddhamadho tiriyaṁ sabbadhi sabbattatāya sabbāvantaṁ lokaṁ mettāsahagatena cetasā vipulena mahaggatena appamāṇena averena abyābajjhena pharitvā vihāsi.
root_text.mn83:17-19.5: upekkhāsahagatena cetasā ekaṁ disaṁ pharitvā vihāsi, tathā dutiyaṁ, tathā tatiyaṁ, tathā catutthaṁ; iti uddhamadho tiriyaṁ sabbadhi sabbattatāya sabbāvantaṁ lokaṁ upekkhāsahagatena cetasā vipulena mahaggatena appamāṇena averena abyābajjhena pharitvā vihāsi.
root_text.mn83:17-19.6: Nimi kho panānanda, rājā caturāsītivassasahassāni kumārakīḷitaṁ kīḷi, caturāsītivassasahassāni oparajjaṁ kāresi, caturāsītivassasahassāni rajjaṁ kāresi, caturāsītivassasahassāni imasmiṁyeva maghadevaambavane agārasmā anagāriyaṁ pabbajito brahmacariyamacari.
root_text.mn83:17-19.7: So cattāro brahmavihāre bhāvetvā kāyassa bhedā paraṁ maraṇā brahmalokūpago ahosi.
root_text.mn83:20.1: Nimissa kho panānanda, rañño kaḷārajanako nāma putto ahosi.
root_text.mn83:21.1: Siyā kho pana te, ānanda, evamassa:
root_text.mn83:21.2: ‘añño nūna tena samayena rājā maghadevo ahosi, yena taṁ kalyāṇaṁ vattaṁ nihitan’ti.
root_text.mn83:21.3: Na kho panetaṁ, ānanda, evaṁ daṭṭhabbaṁ.
root_text.mn83:21.4: Ahaṁ tena samayena rājā maghadevo ahosiṁ.
root_text.mn83:21.5: Ahaṁ taṁ kalyāṇaṁ vattaṁ nihiniṁ, mayā taṁ kalyāṇaṁ vattaṁ nihitaṁ;
root_text.mn83:21.7: Taṁ kho panānanda, kalyāṇaṁ vattaṁ na nibbidāya na virāgāya na nirodhāya na upasamāya na abhiññāya na sambodhāya na nibbānāya saṁvattati, yāvadeva brahmalokūpapattiyā.
root_text.mn83:21.8: Idaṁ kho panānanda, etarahi mayā kalyāṇaṁ vattaṁ nihitaṁ ekantanibbidāya virāgāya nirodhāya upasamāya abhiññāya sambodhāya nibbānāya saṁvattati.
root_text.mn83:21.9: Katamañcānanda, etarahi mayā kalyāṇaṁ vattaṁ nihitaṁ ekantanibbidāya virāgāya nirodhāya upasamāya abhiññāya sambodhāya nibbānāya saṁvattati?
root_text.mn83:21.11: sammādiṭṭhi, sammāsaṅkappo, sammāvācā, sammākammanto, sammāājīvo, sammāvāyāmo, sammāsati, sammāsamādhi.
root_text.mn83:21.12: Idaṁ kho, ānanda, etarahi mayā kalyāṇaṁ vattaṁ nihitaṁ ekantanibbidāya virāgāya nirodhāya upasamāya abhiññāya sambodhāya nibbānāya saṁvattati.
root_text.mn83:21.13: Taṁ vo ahaṁ, ānanda, evaṁ vadāmi:
root_text.mn83:21.14: ‘yena me idaṁ kalyāṇaṁ vattaṁ nihitaṁ anuppavatteyyātha, mā kho me tumhe antimapurisā ahuvattha’.
root_text.mn83:21.15: Yasmiṁ kho, ānanda, purisayuge vattamāne evarūpassa kalyāṇassa vattassa samucchedo hoti so tesaṁ antimapuriso hoti.
root_text.mn83:21.16: Taṁ vo ahaṁ, ānanda, evaṁ vadāmi:
root_text.mn83:21.17: ‘yena me idaṁ kalyāṇaṁ vattaṁ nihitaṁ anuppavatteyyātha, mā kho me tumhe antimapurisā ahuvatthā’”ti.
root_text.mn83:21.19: Attamano āyasmā ānando bhagavato bhāsitaṁ abhinandīti.

translation_text.mn83:1.2: At one time the Buddha was staying near Mithilā in the Maghadeva Mango Grove.
translation_text.mn83:2.1: Then the Buddha smiled at a certain spot.
translation_text.mn83:2.3: “What is the cause, what is the reason why the Buddha smiled?
translation_text.mn83:2.4: Realized Ones do not smile for no reason.”
translation_text.mn83:2.5: So Ānanda arranged his robe over one shoulder, raised his joined palms toward the Buddha, and said,
translation_text.mn83:2.6: “What is the cause, what is the reason why the Buddha smiled?
translation_text.mn83:2.7: Realized Ones do not smile for no reason.”
translation_text.mn83:3.1: “Once upon a time, Ānanda, right here in Mithilā there was a just and principled king named Maghadeva, a great king who stood by his duty.
translation_text.mn83:3.2: He justly treated brahmins and householders, and people of town and country.
translation_text.mn83:3.3: And he observed the sabbath on the fourteenth, fifteenth, and eighth of the fortnight.
translation_text.mn83:4.1: Then, after many years, many hundred years, many thousand years had passed, King Maghadeva addressed his barber,
translation_text.mn83:4.2: ‘My dear barber, when you see grey hairs growing on my head, please tell me.’
translation_text.mn83:4.4: When many thousand years had passed, the barber saw grey hairs growing on the king’s head.
translation_text.mn83:4.6: ‘The messengers of the gods have shown themselves to you. Grey hairs can be seen growing on your head.’
translation_text.mn83:4.7: ‘Well then, my dear barber, carefully pull them out with tweezers and place them in my cupped hands.’
translation_text.mn83:4.8: ‘Yes, Your Majesty,’ replied the barber, and he did as the king said.
translation_text.mn83:4.9: The king gave the barber a prize village, then summoned the crown prince and said,
translation_text.mn83:4.10: ‘Dear prince, the messengers of the gods have shown themselves to me.
translation_text.mn83:4.11: Grey hairs can be seen growing on my head.
translation_text.mn83:4.13: Now it is time to seek heavenly pleasures.
translation_text.mn83:4.14: Come, dear prince, rule the realm.
translation_text.mn83:4.15: I shall shave off my hair and beard, dress in ocher robes, and go forth from the lay life to homelessness.
translation_text.mn83:4.16: For dear prince, you too will one day see grey hairs growing on your head. When this happens, after giving a prize village to the barber and carefully instructing the crown prince in kingship, you should shave off your hair and beard, dress in ocher robes, and go forth from the lay life to homelessness.
translation_text.mn83:4.17: Keep up this good practice that I have founded. Do not be my final man.
translation_text.mn83:4.18: When a pair of men are living, the one who breaks such good practice is their final man.
translation_text.mn83:4.20: “Keep up this good practice that I have founded. Do not be my final man.”’
translation_text.mn83:5.1: And so, after giving a prize village to the barber and carefully instructing the crown prince in kingship, King Maghadeva shaved off his hair and beard, dressed in ocher robes, and went forth from the lay life to homelessness here in this mango grove.
translation_text.mn83:5.2: He meditated spreading a heart full of love to one direction, and to the second, and to the third, and to the fourth. In the same way above, below, across, everywhere, all around, he spread a heart full of love to the whole world—abundant, expansive, limitless, free of enmity and ill will.
translation_text.mn83:5.3: He meditated spreading a heart full of compassion …
translation_text.mn83:5.5: equanimity to one direction, and to the second, and to the third, and to the fourth. In the same way above, below, across, everywhere, all around, he spread a heart full of equanimity to the whole world—abundant, expansive, limitless, free of enmity and ill will.
translation_text.mn83:6.1: For 84,000 years King Maghadeva played games as a child, for 84,000 years he acted as viceroy, for 84,000 years he ruled the realm, and for 84,000 years he led the spiritual life after going forth here in this mango grove.
translation_text.mn83:6.2: And having developed the four divine meditations, when his body broke up, after death, he was reborn in a good place, a realm of divinity.
translation_text.mn83:7.1: Then, after many years, many hundred years, many thousand years had passed, King Maghadeva’s son addressed his barber,
translation_text.mn83:7.2: ‘My dear barber, when you see grey hairs growing on my head, please tell me.’
translation_text.mn83:7.3: And all unfolded as in the case of his father.
translation_text.mn83:9.7: And having developed the four divine meditations, when his body broke up, after death, Maghadeva’s son was reborn in a good place, a realm of divinity.
translation_text.mn83:10.1: And a lineage of 84,000 kings, sons of sons of King Maghadeva, shaved off their hair and beard, dressed in ocher robes, and went forth from the lay life to homelessness here in this mango grove.
translation_text.mn83:10.2: They meditated spreading a heart full of love …
translation_text.mn83:11.3: equanimity to one direction, and to the second, and to the third, and to the fourth. In the same way above, below, across, everywhere, all around, they spread a heart full of equanimity to the whole world—abundant, expansive, limitless, free of enmity and ill will.
translation_text.mn83:11.4: For 84,000 years they played games as a child, for 84,000 years they acted as viceroy, for 84,000 years they ruled the realm, and for 84,000 years they led the spiritual life after going forth here in this mango grove.
translation_text.mn83:11.5: And having developed the four divine meditations, when their bodies broke up, after death, they were reborn in a good place, a realm of divinity.
translation_text.mn83:12.1: Nimi was the last of those kings, a just and principled king, a great king who stood by his duty.
translation_text.mn83:12.2: He justly treated brahmins and householders, and people of town and country.
translation_text.mn83:12.3: And he observed the sabbath on the fourteenth, fifteenth, and eighth of the fortnight.
translation_text.mn83:13.1: Once upon a time, Ānanda, while the gods of the thirty-three were sitting together in the Hall of Clear Right, this discussion came up among them:
translation_text.mn83:13.2: ‘The people of Videha are so fortunate, so very fortunate
translation_text.mn83:13.3: to have Nimi as their king. He is a just and principled king, a great king who stands by his duty.
translation_text.mn83:13.4: He justly treats brahmins and householders, and people of town and country.
translation_text.mn83:13.5: And he observes the sabbath on the fourteenth, fifteenth, and eighth of the fortnight.’
translation_text.mn83:13.6: Then Sakka, lord of gods, addressed the gods of the thirty-three,
translation_text.mn83:13.7: ‘Good fellows, would you like to see King Nimi?’
translation_text.mn83:13.9: Now at that time it was the fifteenth day sabbath, and King Nimi had bathed his head and was sitting upstairs in the royal longhouse to observe the sabbath.
translation_text.mn83:13.10: Then, as easily as a strong person would extend or contract their arm, Sakka vanished from the thirty-three gods and reappeared in front of King Nimi.
translation_text.mn83:13.12: ‘You’re fortunate, great king, so very fortunate.
translation_text.mn83:13.13: The gods of the thirty-three were sitting together in the Hall of Clear Right, where they were singing your praises.
translation_text.mn83:13.18: They would like to see you.
translation_text.mn83:13.19: I shall send a chariot harnessed with a thousand thoroughbreds for you, great king.
translation_text.mn83:13.20: Mount the heavenly chariot, great king, without wavering!’
translation_text.mn83:13.22: Then, knowing that the king had consented, as easily as a strong person would extend or contract their arm, Sakka vanished from King Nimi and reappeared among the gods of the thirty-three.
translation_text.mn83:14.1: Then Sakka, lord of gods, addressed his chariot handler Mātali,
translation_text.mn83:14.2: ‘Come, dear Mātali, harness the chariot with a thousand thoroughbreds. Then go to King Nimi and say,
translation_text.mn83:14.3: “Great king, this chariot has been sent for you by Sakka, lord of gods.
translation_text.mn83:14.4: Mount the heavenly chariot, great king, without wavering!”’
translation_text.mn83:14.5: ‘Yes, lord,’ replied Mātali. He did as Sakka asked, and said to the king,
translation_text.mn83:14.6: ‘Great king, this chariot has been sent for you by Sakka, lord of gods.
translation_text.mn83:14.7: Mount the heavenly chariot, great king, without wavering!
translation_text.mn83:14.8: But which way should we go—the way of those who experience the result of bad deeds, or the way of those who experience the result of good deeds?’
translation_text.mn83:15.1: Mātali brought King Nimi to the Hall of Clear Right.
translation_text.mn83:15.2: Sakka saw King Nimi coming off in the distance,
translation_text.mn83:15.6: The gods of the thirty-three who wanted to see you were sitting together in the Hall of Clear Right, where they were singing your praises.
translation_text.mn83:15.11: The gods of the thirty-three would like to see you.
translation_text.mn83:15.12: Enjoy heavenly glory among the gods!’
translation_text.mn83:15.13: ‘Enough, good fellow. Send me back to Mithilā right away.
translation_text.mn83:15.14: That way I shall justly treat brahmins and householders, and people of town and country.
translation_text.mn83:15.15: And I shall observe the sabbath on the fourteenth, fifteenth, and eighth of the fortnight.’
translation_text.mn83:16.1: Then Sakka, lord of gods, addressed his chariot handler Mātali,
translation_text.mn83:16.2: ‘Come, dear Mātali, harness the chariot with a thousand thoroughbreds and send King Nimi back to Mithilā right away.’
translation_text.mn83:16.3: ‘Yes, lord,’ replied Mātali, and did as Sakka asked.
translation_text.mn83:16.4: And there King Nimi justly treated his people, and observed the sabbath.
translation_text.mn83:16.5: Then, after many years, many hundred years, many thousand years had passed, King Nimi addressed his barber,
translation_text.mn83:16.6: ‘My dear barber, when you see grey hairs growing on my head, please tell me.’
translation_text.mn83:17-19.7: And having developed the four divine meditations, when his body broke up, after death, King Nimi was reborn in a good place, a realm of divinity.
translation_text.mn83:20.1: But King Nimi had a son named Kaḷāra Janaka.
translation_text.mn83:20.2: He didn’t go forth from the lay life to homelessness.
translation_text.mn83:21.2: ‘Surely King Maghadeva, by whom that good practice was founded, must have been someone else at that time?’
translation_text.mn83:21.3: But you should not see it like this.
translation_text.mn83:21.4: I myself was King Maghadeva at that time.
translation_text.mn83:21.5: I was the one who founded that good practice,
translation_text.mn83:21.6: which was kept up by those who came after.
translation_text.mn83:21.7: But that good practice doesn’t lead to disillusionment, dispassion, cessation, peace, insight, awakening, and extinguishment. It only leads as far as rebirth in the realm of divinity.
translation_text.mn83:21.8: But now I have founded a good practice that does lead to disillusionment, dispassion, cessation, peace, insight, awakening, and extinguishment.
translation_text.mn83:21.9: And what is that good practice?
translation_text.mn83:21.10: It is simply this noble eightfold path, that is:
translation_text.mn83:21.11: right view, right thought, right speech, right action, right livelihood, right effort, right mindfulness, and right immersion.
translation_text.mn83:21.12: This is the good practice I have now founded that leads to disillusionment, dispassion, cessation, peace, insight, awakening, and extinguishment.
translation_text.mn83:21.14: ‘You all should keep up this good practice that I have founded. Do not be my final men.’
translation_text.mn83:21.15: When a pair of men are living, the one who breaks such good practice is their final man.
translation_text.mn83:21.17: ‘You all should keep up this good practice that I have founded. Do not be my final men.’”
translation_text.mn83:21.18: That is what the Buddha said.
translation_text.mn83:21.19: Satisfied, Venerable Ānanda approved what the Buddha said.
